THE ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE & CONTINGENCY POLICIES FOR OUR FACILITY.

The Facility complies with the 1989 ANSI K61.1 "Safety Requirments for the Storage and Handleling of Anhydrous Ammonia." In addition, it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.

One of our company goals states, "To provide for the Safety and Security of our employees, our customers, the general public and to be good stuartsof the environment for which we serve." To fulfill these goals, we enroll in requlatory management service that assists in maintaining and administer comprehensive safety and environmental programs, procedures, and training coures. We preforma thorough annual audit program and monitor facility compliance with the safety standards and overseen assistance with this speciality firm. The program consists of iternal audit utilizing checklists survey forms that are reviewded regularly and updated as necessary to ensure all applicable federal, state, and local regulations are covered. The checklists are used to measure regulatory compliance including those governing the safe handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia. Procedures require a timely response and correction of all recommendations resulting from these audit checklists.

A 'Site Safety Coordinator' is identified and used as an extension of the general manager and management service personnel for a "hands on" manager of the day to day safe working activities, maintain the required regulatory recordkeeping, conduct monthly safety meetings, conduct employee training and act as the location's contact during emergency incidents that are rehearsed diannually. 

A DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Th facility is a wholesale farm supply and distribution center and such as we store and distribute a wide variety of pesticides a

nd fertilizers including anhydrous ammonia. Anhydrous Ammonia is received by truck, is handled and stored on-site and is regulated substance by the EPA requireing us to comply with this Risk Management Program. We sell anhydrous ammonia to growers in nurse tanks manufactured to the requirements to do such. The customer applies the ammonia into the soil as a needed source of nitrogen fertilizers for crop production nurtrients.

Our facility maintains 2 - 30,000 gallon stationary storage tanks on site.

WORST CASE SCENARIO

Our worst case scenario is the loss of the total contents of the 2-30,000 gallon storage tanks, when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% capacity), released as a gas over 10 mins, resulting total vaporization. The maximum quanity released would be 140,000 pounds. According to DEGADIS modeling, the distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) would have off-site impact. It should be noted that our company has never had a total release of an entire storage tank.

ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO

The most common alternate release scenario from an anhydrous ammonia storage facility would not reach an endpoint off-site. The alternate release scenarion modeled for the purpose of this plan is a two-minute release from a stationary storage tank representing a valve and hose failure requring a manual shutdown. The total amount of anhydrous ammonia released in this scenario would be 12,000 pounds from a storage tank. The distance to the endpoint would have no impact.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELAESE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The ammonia storage system is designed, installed and maintained in accordance with ASTM standards and the ASME codes. This facility complies with the ANSI K61.1 standard ( 1989 edition), OSHA-29 CFR 1910.111, EPA's Accendetal Release Prevention Rule as well as all applicable federal, state, and local codes and regulations.

Our ammonia system is protected from major release by intrenal excess f

low valves, check valves, relief valves, manual shutoffs and emergency shutoff valve. The load-out risers used for the purpose of filling the nurse tanks are protected by excess flow valves and fill lines breakaways to immediatley stop the flow of ammonia if a line or a hose would fail. All the main storage tank valves and the risers are locked when not in use. Lighting for the facility has increased to discourge the increase in meth theft.

Our anhydrous ammonia system is inspected on a regular basis with maintenance and preventitive maintenace scheduled and documented. Liquid and vapor valves, hoses, excess flow valves, guages, and relief valves are replaced when necessary and/or according to the guidelines within the ANSI standards.

Training is provided to all employess at least annually, whenever there is a change in the process or whenever completency with regulations are questioned. In accordance with the 1989 ANSI standards, training is also offered for all ammonia customers to attended on a regular basis and offered to the local fire department personnel during their annual tour of our facility and operations. These training courses consist of classroom lecture, current and approved videos or compact discs, testing both verbally and written, demstration and observation for each person working with the process that are certified while on-going job training is always improved upon.

FIVE YEAR ACCIENT HISTORY

There has been no accidents involving anhydrous ammonia that has caused deaths, recordable injuries, property or environmental damage including evacuation on or off site.

The 'EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND CONTINGENCY PLAN'

In the event of an emergency involving our ammonia system, it is our policy to notify the local communtiy fire department and request that they respond to the emergency with the facility's personnel assistance. In preparation for this, we have coordinated with all of the local response agencies by providing information and facility tours a

nnually to ensure that they are familiar with and properly prepared for an incident at our facility. This will help to ensure that our community has the strategy for responding to and mitigating the threat posed by an ammonia release. This complies with the requirement or facility to be included in the community emergency response plan prepared under EPCRA and coordinated with our LEPC.
